pullRequest.body:
Extend the `setOption` linter to warn on autoImplicit true outside of `tests`.

This linter is off by default and activated in mathlib only.

---

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [f93b9c66bc](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17109/commits/f93b9c66bccb8a22b0930f9e3297a159d2d1d613)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ tactic5`
`- is_set_option`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

On zulip, Mario [expressed unhappiness](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Technical.20Debt.20Counters/near/472728220) with this linter, comparing this to 
> having a dialog saying "are you sure you want to press Yes on the 'are you sure you want to quit' dialog?"

From a Lean core perspective, this makes sense. `autoImplicit` is enabled there, so mathlib's configuration is the odd one out, and having to jump through hoops on re-enabling it in mathlib feels like the warning fatigue above.
Let me propose a different phrasing, coming from the perspective of a math user in mathlib, I claim that using `autoImplicit` is either unknown or surprising. (Indeed, common advice when teaching Lean in some form is to turn off that option, as the first thing you're doing.) Living just in math-land, autoImplicit is always off, and having a warning on activating it makes sense.

From a pragmatic view-point: I claim that mathlib reviewers would usually reject PRs adding that option. This linter just codifies this internal convention, saving reviewer time.

> I claim that using `autoImplicit` is either unknown or surprising.

This linter only fires when you opt in, not when you forget to opt-out, right? So this wouldn't help any new users in a project that was not configured with a different detault.

> > I claim that using `autoImplicit` is either unknown or surprising.
> 
> This linter only fires when you opt in, not when you forget to opt-out, right? So this wouldn't help any new users in a project that was not configured with a different detault.

Indeed. It could help users in mathlib - and for any project downstream that decides to adopt this linter.

> I agree with Eric that this linter is mostly useful if you know about it and, if you know about it, you probably also know about autoImplicits anyway.

I think my message above might not have been clear enough; this linter only helps people who literally type `set_option autoImplcit true`, right? I think all the beginners running into errors here (mathlib or otherwise) are people who _didn't type this_, and so this doesn't help them.

Is this warning just intended to ensure we don't merge new `set_option autoImplicit true`s into mathlib?

This comment is spot on: it's just about this.
> Is this warning just intended to ensure we don't merge new set_option autoImplicit trues into mathlib?

This linter does not address teaching newcomers about this pitfall, nor about e.g. changing the lakefile template for math projects. These could be worthwhile, but are out of scope of this PR.
I agree with Eric that this linter is mostly useful if you know about it and, if you know about it, you probably also know about autoImplicits anyway.
I agree with Eric that this linter is mostly useful if you know about it and, if you know about it, you probably also know about autoImplicits anyway.
You need to patch Lean core to add a `withAntiquot` on `Lean.Parser.Command.optionValue`.

```suggestion
        if name == `autoImplicit && val.raw matches .atom _ "true" then
```
or similar
Thanks!

```suggestion
def parse_set_option : Syntax → Option (Syntax × TSyntax [`str, `num])
```
You could return the identifier itself, rather than composing with `getId`, to collect position information.
... and then here you could match directly on the output of `parse_set_option` and extract the `Syntax` node where to log the exception.
Indeed, that is much nicer. Changed.

pullRequest.title: feat: warn on `autoImplicit true`

This linter does not address teaching newcomers about this pitfall, nor about e.g. changing the lakefile template for math projects. These could be worthwhile, but are out of scope of this PR.
